dt: {bc}of, relating to, or being a grammatical case {dx_def}see {dxt|case:1||3a}{/dx_def} that marks the direct object of a verb or the object of some prepositions

et: Middle English {it}accusatif,{/it} borrowed from Anglo-French, borrowed from Latin {it}accūsātīvus,{/it} from {it}accūsātus{/it} (past participle of {it}accūsāre{/it} "to find fault with, {et_link|accuse|accuse}") + {it}-īvus{/it} {et_link|-ive|-ive}

{it}Accūsātīvus{/it} is the Latin translation of Greek ({it}ptôsis{/it}) {it}aitiatikḗ{/it}; the early Roman grammarians who coined it presumably had in mind the verb {it}aitiâsthai,{/it} which means both "to accuse, censure" and "to allege as the cause." The base of {it}aitiâsthai{/it} is {it}aitía,{/it} which corresponds approximately in meaning with {it}causa,{/it} the base of {it}accūsāre.{/it} Nonetheless, if {it}ptôsis aitiatikḗ{/it} is the "causal case," {it}cāsus accūsātīvus{/it} does not really convey the same idea, and the translation is more apt etymologically than literally.
shortdef: of, relating to, or being a grammatical case that marks the direct object of a verb or the object of some prepositions

dt: {bc}the accusative case of a language {bc}a form in the accusative case

et: Middle English {it}accusatif,{/it} borrowed from Anglo-French, borrowed from Latin {it}accūsātīvus,{/it} from {it}accūsātīvus{/it} {et_link|accusative:1|accusative:1}
shortdef: the accusative case of a language : a form in the accusative case
